Just for informational purposes, here is a summary of the legal reasoning behind permitting the police to lie to suspects during interrogations. 
 
 The Constitution requires that all confessions be voluntarily made. If a statement is proven to have been involuntarily made (made while being tortured, to give an extreme example), then the Court would apply the exclusionary rule and suppress the statement. 
 
 Lying to suspects is not encouraged by the courts. When it happens, however, it does not automatically require suppression of a confession. It becomes merely one factor to consider when a Court decides whether a "confession" was freely and voluntarily made as opposed to being the product of coercion. Here are two quotes from a Virginia case which give a good explanation of this reasoning:
 
 1. The voluntariness requirement. 
 
 "The test for voluntariness derives from federal constitutional law relating to the Fifth Amendment as applied to the States through the Fourteenth Amendment. In Stockton, we relied upon Schneckloth v. Bustamonte, 412 U.S. 218, 225 (1973), and concluded that in order to determine whether a statement is voluntary, we must decide, in light of the totality of the circumstances, whether the statement is the product of an essentially free and unconstrained choice by its maker, or whether the maker's will has been overborne and his capacity for self-determination critically impaired. 227 Va. at 140, 314 S.E.2d at 381."
 
 Rodgers v. Commonwealth, 227 Va. 605, 609, 318 S.E.2d 298, ___ (1984)
 
 2. How lying to suspects fits in the totality of the circumstances:
 
 "Even a lie on the part of an interrogating police officer does not, in and of itself, require a finding that a resulting confession was involuntary. In Frazier v. Cupp, 394 U.S. 731 (1969), the Supreme Court made clear that even an outright falsehood by a police interrogator is but another factor to be considered in evaluating the totality of the circumstances. In Frazier the officer told the defendant that one of the defendant's friends had confessed. This was false. The defendant, after some further hesitation, confessed. He argued that the falsehood rendered his confession involuntary. Justice Marshall, writing for the Court, rejected that argument:
 
 The fact that the police misrepresented the statements that Rawls had made is, while relevant, insufficient in our view to make this otherwise voluntary confession inadmissible. These cases must be decided by viewing the "totality of the circumstances," see, e.g., Clewis v. Texas, 386 U.S. 707, 708 (1967), and on the facts of this case we can find no error in the admission of petitioner's confession.
 
 394 U.S. at 739."
 
 Rodgers v. Commonwealth, 227 Va. 605, 616, 318 S.E.2d 298, ___ (1984)
